Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story: It’s Saturday morning, and I’m standing in the kitchen, coffee in hand, staring at the overflowing laundry basket. My wife’s voice echoes from the hallway, reminding me that the kids need clean clothes for their soccer game tomorrow. I nod, feeling the weight of her expectation—she’s been handling most of the chores lately, and I promised to help more. Just as I reach for the detergent, my phone buzzes. Slack notifications light up the screen: “Urgent—users can’t log in again. Need a fix ASAP.” My team is counting on me; the bug has been haunting us all week, and the pressure from QA is mounting. I glance at the laundry, then at my laptop on the dining table, heart pounding. Both roles demand my attention, both feel urgent, and I can’t shake the guilt that whichever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
